title: Audit and update shadcn/ui components
description:
After all major version upgrades are complete, audit current shadcn/ui 
components and check if:
1. New components have been added to shadcn that we should consider adding
2. Existing component APIs have changed and need migration
3. Component versions can be safely updated
4. New patterns/patterns are recommended in shadcn ecosystem

Run: npx shadcn-ui@latest list to see new components
Check: https://ui.shadcn.com for recent additions/changes

title: Audit and fix package.json devDependencies vs dependencies
description:
Ensure all packages are correctly categorized as:
- devDependencies: Build tools, linters, type definitions, dev servers
- dependencies: Runtime libraries needed at production

Current issues to check:
1. Review all @types/* packages - should be devDependencies only
2. Review build/dev tools: prettier, eslint, tailwindcss, postcss, autoprefixer
3. Review Redux ecosystem - what's actually needed at runtime vs dev
4. Check Radix UI - all should be runtime dependencies
5. Verify testing libraries are devDependencies
6. Check if tailwindcss is correctly placed (likely should stay in devDependencies 
   for Next.js)

This affects:
- Bundle size at production
- Installation speed for end users
- CI/CD optimization

Run: npm audit to check for issues after reorganizing

title: Phase 10: Node Version Constraint Review
description:
Node Version Constraint Review - Risk: Low

Rationale: After all dependencies upgraded, check if we can require a newer Node version.

Steps: Check minimum Node requirements of all packages (check pnpm-lock.yaml), consider bumping engines.node from ^18.0.0 to ^18.17.0 or ^20.0.0, update package.json, pnpm install and full test on target Node version, commit.

Rollback if: Incompatibility with target Node version

description: Upgrade Next.js from 13.5.11 to 14.x. Check @types/react, @types/react-dom, eslint-config-next, and next-redux-wrapper for compatibility. Run full typecheck, lint, and build to verify. Document any breaking changes found.

title: Phase 7: React Dependents (Radix UI, react-day-picker)
description:
React Dependents (Radix UI, react-day-picker) - Risk: Medium

Rationale: Depend on React. After React upgraded, upgrade all React-dependent utilities together.

Packages: react-day-picker ^8.8.0 → ^8.latest, @react-hookz/web ^23.1.0 → ^24.latest, @tanstack/react-table ^8.9.3 → ^8.latest, all @radix-ui/* packages (v1.x or v2.x)

Steps: Update versions, pnpm install, pnpm typecheck, pnpm lint && pnpm build, thorough manual testing with pnpm dev (test all Radix components, interactions, responsive design), commit.

Rollback if: Type errors, component API changes, visual regressions

title: Audit Radix UI, Tailwind, and other dependency updates for custom components
description:
After all major version upgrades are complete, audit custom components and 
dependencies for potential updates:

1. Review @radix-ui/* package upgrades (especially react-select, popover, etc.)
2. Check Tailwind CSS v4+ migration impact on custom component utilities
3. Verify all UI utilities from imported libs (lucide-react, tailwind-merge, etc.) 
   are using the latest APIs
4. Test for any component rendering regressions or visual changes
5. Update component code patterns if newer libraries provide better APIs

This is separate from shadcn components as it focuses on base libraries and custom 
component implementations.

title: Prepare for ESLint 9: Review flat config migration path
description:
Prepare for ESLint 9 by migrating to flat config format.

MIGRATION STRATEGY:
Phase 1: Config Format Migration (6.1, 6.2, 6.3) - ESLint 8 only
- 6.1 (DONE): Create eslint.config.mjs with FlatCompat bridge
- 6.2 (DONE): Verify flat config works with Next.js 15 and all plugins
- 6.3: Minimize FlatCompat - rewrite to pure native flat config
- Benefit: Separates config format change from version upgrade

Phase 2: ESLint Version Upgrade (8, 9) - depends on 6.3
- Task 8: Upgrade ESLint 8.x → 9.x (after 6.3 complete)
- Task 9: Upgrade @typescript-eslint 7.x → 8.x (for ESLint 9 compatibility)
- Timing: Both done together since they're tightly coupled

Phase 3: ESLint 10 Upgrade (10) - depends on Next.js 16
- Task 10: Upgrade ESLint 9.x → 10.x (after Next.js 16 migration)
- Reason: ESLint 10 may have different Next.js integration requirements

WHY THIS APPROACH:
- Each phase is independently testable
- Separates concerns: config format, version upgrades, framework compatibility
- Minimal risk per step - easier to diagnose issues
- Follows ESLint and Next.js official migration guidance

title: Migrate .eslintrc.json to eslint.config.js flat config format
description:
Migrate .eslintrc.json to eslint.config.mjs using FlatCompat bridge.

COMPLETED CHANGES:
- Created eslint.config.mjs with FlatCompat wrapper around .eslintrc.json
- FlatCompat bridges old JSON config to flat config format (ESLint 8 compatible)
- Updated lint scripts to use ESLint CLI: 'eslint .' instead of 'next lint'
- Added @eslint/eslintrc and @eslint/js as devDependencies
- Fixed tailwind.config.js ESLint issues with disable comments
- Properly configured ignores: src/components/ui, next-env.d.ts, .next, .beads, etc.

WHY FLATCOMPAT:
- Minimal risk: No rewrite of entire .eslintrc.json needed
- Validates flat config works with Next.js 15 and ESLint 8
- Clear separation: Config format change independent of version upgrade
- Proven approach per Next.js official documentation

RESULT: pnpm lint passes cleanly, all plugins functional

title: Verify flat config works with all ESLint plugins and Next.js 15
description:
Verify that flat config (FlatCompat) works with all ESLint plugins and Next.js 15.

- ✅ Build succeeds: pnpm build compiles with all optimizations  
- ✅ Typecheck passes: pnpm typecheck confirms TypeScript strict mode
- ✅ All plugins functional: Next.js, TypeScript, unused-imports all working

RESULT: Flat config validated and working. Ready to proceed to 6.3 (minimize FlatCompat)

title: Upgrade all dependencies to latest stable versions
description:
Comprehensive dependency upgrade plan using dependency isolation strategy.

Phases: 
1. Completely Independent Utilities (✓ COMPLETE)
2. State Utilities (immer, use-immer)
3. TypeScript build tool
4. ESLint & Prettier
5. Tailwind CSS & Styling Utilities
6. React Core (18.x)
7. React Dependents (Radix UI, react-day-picker)
8. Next.js Core
9. Next.js Dependents & Redux
10. Node Version Constraint Review

Strategy: Upgrade packages in order of independence, not category. If a phase breaks, nothing that depends on it in later phases has been upgraded yet.

Testing: Each phase requires pnpm install, pnpm typecheck, pnpm lint, pnpm build, and manual pnpm dev testing.

Rollback: git diff HEAD~1, identify failure, quick fix or git reset --hard HEAD~1 to revert phase.
